Award.AwardTitle: Identifying and resolving discrepancies in kinetic models of hydrocarbon combustion.

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1403171
West

Kinetic modeling of combustion chemistry has made significant progress. Dozens of recent models, which describe tens of thousands of reactions between thousands of intermediate species, are capable of explaining complicated combustion phenomena, allowing increasingly accurate engine simulations. However, these ever-proliferating published models are rarely compared with each other due to a lack of tools. A web-based teaching laboratory suitable for undergraduate chemical engineers will be developed, to introduce combustion science to a wider audience. As part of a summer Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) program a high school STEM teacher will help develop a web-lab for high schools and bring these ideas into the classroom. Several undergraduate and graduate students will gain research experience and training. Efforts will be made to recruit students of under-represented groups to fill these positions. The results will be presented at conferences, published in journals, and included in an interactive web-database.

This project develops tools to help identify of chemical species in a kinetic model that facilitate comparison of models. The tools will be built upon the open-source Reaction Mechanism Generator (RMG) software. A web-based user interface will make it easy for users to import models to the database, and provide instant reward for doing so (the ability to check the model, fill in gaps, and merge with other models). The proposed work will massively reduce the barriers to converting detailed kinetic models into a machine-readable format with unambiguous and consistent species definitions. This will enable: (1) comparison between models, leading to more replicable science, (2) error identification, leading to higher quality data, (3) better rate estimates and a broader impact for mechanism generation software, and (4) wider use of process informatics tools. The unified database of all previous kinetic models will greatly assist progress in combustion modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Progress in detailed kinetic modeling of combustion chemistry is significant; dozens of recent kinetic models, which describe tens of thousands of reactions between thousands of intermediate species, can explain complicated combustion phenomena and allow increasingly accurate engine simulations. However, these ever-proliferating published models are rarely compared with each other, or checked for mistakes, because no tools existed to do so.

The challenge was in identifying the chemical species, which are only given short names in most published models. For example, the name “C3KET12” in a model represents a certain chemical species (1-hydroperoxypropan-2-one), which another research group may have named “CH3COCH2O2H” in a different model.

This project developed a tool to facilitate identification of chemical species in a kinetic model, and to allow comparison of models once the species have been identified. We have collected 91 published models from academic literature, the World Wide Web, and directly from authors, and have identified over 19,000 chemical species in the models. This allowed us to detect some errors within models, such as duplicated species, and significant discrepancies between models, such as reaction rates that differ by several orders of magnitude, and enthalpies of formation that differ by tens of kilojoules per mole.

The project massively reduced the barriers to converting detailed kinetic models, published by the combustion research community, into a machine-readable format with unambiguous and consistent species definitions. Use of this tool will enable comparison between models, leading to a host of benefits including, but not limited to:
- more replicable science;
- error identification, leading to higher quality data;
- better rate estimates and a broader impact for mechanism generation software; and
- wider use of process informatics tools. The unified database of all previous kinetic models will greatly assist progress in combustion modeling.

The software developed under this project to import kinetic models and identify the species therein, is open-source and developed in public, with the latest version and full development history available at https://github.com/rwest/RMG-Py/tree/importer. An example for use is at https://github.com/rwest/RMG-Py/tree/importer/examples/chemkinImporter/USC_Mech_ii. Furthermore, a snapshot from the end of the project (with full version history) is archived at https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.4787893.v1.

The project is also described in a poster (B. Slakman, P. Bhoorasingh, R. West (2017): Analyzing Combustion Models Using a Reaction Mechanism Importer Tool. https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.4788892.v1 )

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2017
Modified by: Richard H West

We have collected 91 published models from academic literature, the World Wide Web, and directly from authors, and have identified over 19,000 chemical species in the models.
